title: 'Smart condom' detects STIs and tells you how many calories you burn during sex
text:
News 'Smart condom' detects STIs and tells you how many calories you burn during sex The i.Con Smart Condom detects the number and speed of your thrusts - sort of like a Fitbit for your penis Share A smart 'condom' that monitors your performance in the bedroom - as well as detecting sexually transmitted infections (STIs) - is being developed (Photo: Westend61) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! A smart 'condom' which monitors your performance in the bedroom - as well as detecting sexually transmitted infections (STIs) - is being developed. 
The i.Con Smart Condom will monitor calories burnt, duration of intercourse and number of thrusts and then relay the information to a smartphone app via Bluetooth. 
Using nano-chip and sensors it can also detect the speed of your thrusts and how many different positions you use - then tell you how you stack up to other people from around the world. 
Despite the name, the item is not actually a condom. The i-Con Smart Condom is billed as a new form of wearable technology (Photo: SWNS) 
It’s a ring that will sit over a condom at the base, which you can use over and over again. 
"It is extremely comfortable, water resistant and lightweight, you won’t even know it’s there ensuring maximum pleasure and, peace of mind," according to its manufacturers. Read More 
Nottinghamshire-based British Condoms said the project brought new meaning to the term "wearable tech" - and that nearly 100,000 people have pre-registered for the £59.99 product. Despite the name, the item is not actually a condom (Photo: Getty) 
Adam Leverson, lead engineer on the i.Con project, said: "Not only have we innovated the world's first smart condom ring that'll measure pretty much every aspect of performance in the bedroom, but now I'm pleased to confirm that it will also have built-in indicators to alert the users to any potential STIs present." 
And if you want to charge it up, just use the micro USB port on the device, that you can plug into your computer or mains. 
The i.Con is currently in the final stages of testing before its release later this year. Like us on Facebook
